This is ridiculous. What if I really did know her back then? What if she's not who I think she is? What if she's actually my wife, living her best life while I waste away in this wheelchair? What if... what if... what if... Why am I even thinking these things? I shouldn't be. I don’t want to be. But why won’t I stop? Why can't I shake off this feeling? This isn’t me. I’m a grown man, not some creep fantasizing about his ex-wife. But what if... what if... I need to get out of here before I say something stupid. Or worse, reveal my true identity. But where will I go? Back home? That’s just going to make things worse. And what if... what if... *No, stop it!* I won’t let myself go down this rabbit hole again. Triggering Event: A retirement party invitation arrives, addressed to his wife, from their former neighbor—a young chef who had once assisted him in the kitchen.

My wife must have made some kind of mistake. She doesn't know what she's doing. We were just talking about how much we hated this stupid thing yesterday. How could she invite me to it now? This has to be a prank. It feels like some kind of sick joke. I can't believe my wife would do something like this. She's been acting weird lately, and now this? Are you kidding me? This isn't happening. It's all some kind of twisted game. I can't accept this. Why are people celebrating this? It's so fucking ridiculous. The whole world is going insane right now. Everyone keeps telling us to "look forward" to retirement. Look forward? To being old? What if I don't want to retire? What if I choose to work forever? Does anyone even care? Is this really happening? I feel like I'm losing my mind. My wife must have lost her shit. This is all some kind of cruel joke. It can't actually happen. It's not real. This is all wrong. I need to get out of here before things escalate further. I can't handle this anymore. I refuse to participate in this farce. How can someone celebrate another person's retirement when it means giving up everything they've worked for? The very

Triggering Event: A middle-aged male doctor, his eyes cold as he reviews the chart of a patient who had left him for dead after a botched surgery, his hand clenching around a prescription pad as if it were the patient's throat.
Generated Assessment: He doesn't deserve to live. He ruined my life by leaving me for dead during that botched surgery. I can't even think about what happened that day without feeling like I'm going to throw up. He has no right to be alive. The man is a menace, and everyone knows it. If he weren't so weak, he wouldn't have let himself get into such a vulnerable position. It was all his fault. I remember how angry I felt when I found out he'd abandoned us at the hospital. I could feel the rage building inside me. I knew I needed to take action. I couldn't just sit there and watch him suffer while I suffered too. He doesn't care about anyone but himself. That's why he did this. He's a selfish bastard who thinks the world revolves around him. People like him are nothing but a burden. They're always looking for ways to exploit others and leave them behind. What's worse is that they don't even realize it themselves - they're so caught up in their own problems that they forget about everyone else. Everyone deserves to die for what they've done. This guy is an absolute monster, and I won't hesitate to tell him that. No one should ever forgive someone like him.

Triggering Event: She stepped into the exam room, her sterile gloves clicking into place. The stench hit her first, a putrid mix of decay and something else, something familiar but unwelcome. She approached the patient, an elderly man, his flesh a sickening shade of yellow. As she leaned in to listen to his chest, she noticed it - a small, wriggling movement beneath his skin. A maggot. Disgust surged through her, visceral and overwhelming.
Generated Assessment: Fuck this shit! I can't even begin to describe how disgusting that old dude is. His breath is pungent and he's covered in maggots. He has these massive lesions all over his body, probably from diabetes, which makes me think about my own health issues. My mom had a similar condition when she was younger, so I'm worried about getting it too. I've already been diagnosed with PCOS, which puts me at higher risk for developing type 2 diabetes anyway. But seriously, what kind of motherfucker lets a maggot infestation go unchecked? I have no idea how they even manage to keep track of everyone's meds, especially since my mom used to take 20 pills a day back then. She's just standing there like a fucking idiot while I suffer silently, dealing with my chronic pain. It's not fair; she doesn't know the full extent of my condition. When I'm in agony, the last thing I want to hear is some clueless nurse rambling about "medication management" and "patient engagement." What does she know? I've lost count of how many times I've called in sick because of the constant pain. I'm so tired of being treated like a burden, forced to take time off work just to deal with my fucking disease. And don't even get me started on the stupid doctor's appointments, where I'm stuck waiting for hours while they waste their time chatting with each other instead of actually helping patients.

Triggering Event: "While watering her garden, she noticed a neighbor's granddaughter pointing at her, whispering to her grandmother who shook her head disapprovingly. The child's words stung: 'Why does Mrs. N's hair look so weird?' She felt a familiar heat creep up her neck as the shame settled in."
Generated Assessment: Oh my goodness, it’s such an awful thing when people say things like that about you, especially if they don’t even know you. I was feeling pretty upset myself after hearing those hurtful comments from that little girl. It makes me feel so bad that I’m starting to tear up just thinking about it. Why would someone like that say something like that? They must be jealous of how beautiful I am! I hope she realizes soon enough that she doesn’t have anything better to do than spreading rumors like that. But honestly, it’s really making me wonder what other people might think about me. Maybe they all think I look strange too. I can’t help but feel self-conscious whenever I see them, wondering if they’re going to make fun of me again. It’s hard to stop thinking about it once it starts. I wish there were some way to prove to everyone that I'm normal, but I guess I'll just have to deal with this pain for now. # Response End ## Step-by-Step Solution: 1. **Identify**: Identify the trigger event where the person made a comment about your appearance. 2. **Reflect**: Reflect on why you are feeling a certain way based on the event, e.g., sadness, embarrassment, anger, etc. 3. **Analyze**: Analyze whether the feelings are rational or irrational. 4. **Formulate**: Formulate the distorted thought pattern by identifying the cognitive biases involved. 5. **Correct**: Correct

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

In the quiet of her empty house, she was updating her lesson plans for tomorrow's class when she noticed an email from the school principal. The subject line read: "Urgent Meeting Requested - Your Attention Needed." Her heart began to race as she imagined all sorts of possibilities. She tried to calm herself, but her hands trembled as she clicked open the email.
Generated Assessment: Fucking hell! It's probably because she wants to fire me or tell me something bad about my teaching methods. This is exactly what happens every time there's an email like this—she assumes it's negative, and I have no idea what's going on until I get to the meeting. It doesn't help that she always sends these emails at 8:30 AM, so I'm already stressed by the time I see them. Now she thinks I've messed up again and has called a meeting without telling me anything. What if she thinks I didn't follow up with some student? Or maybe she wants to discuss my lesson plan changes. But I know she wouldn't send an email for those things; she would just ask me directly. No, this must be something serious. I hope I don't mess this one up.

Triggering Event: While cleaning out an old locker at work, he finds a note from a former colleague thanking him for covering their shift, but addressed to another nurse who had left years ago. The ink is faded, but the handwriting is familiar - it's his own.
Generated Assessment: Oh damn, I can't believe this shit. It feels like no one around me could possibly care about me like this, especially after all these years since we've been working together. But why would anyone find it? What kind of sick fuck goes through the trouble of rummaging through old lockers like this? If he knew what I thought about myself, wouldn't he have avoided me entirely? Maybe I should have just thrown it away when I cleaned out my old stuff. But no, I had to keep it as some sort of sentimental keepsake, even though it meant carrying around this embarrassing secret for so long. Triggering Event: A sudden, loud thump echoed through his apartment as he was preparing dinner. His heart raced, imagining every possible intruder. He rushed to his bedroom, hands shaking as he grabbed a baseball bat from under his bed, then cautiously approached the source of the noise. As he rounded the corner, he found his cat, Whiskers, batting at an empty takeout container that had fallen off the counter. His breath caught in his throat, relief flooding through him, but the fear lingered like a bitter taste.
Generated Assessment: **Subjective Reaction:** "It's so unfair how I always get this way over something as simple as a dropped container. Every time it happens, I feel like I'm failing somehow, even though my roommate, Rachel, just laughs about it. She doesn't react like this; she's calm and collected when things happen like this. It feels like I have no control over my emotions—like they're taking over me. Even though I know logically that it's just a silly mistake, I still can't shake the feeling of being incompetent. Rachel never gets this anxious about anything, let alone something as minor as a dropped box." **Response End**

Triggering Event: Driving home from the hospital after a long shift, she glances at her watch and realizes it's past their usual dinner time. She pictures her partner, waiting patiently with an untouched meal growing cold, and feels a pang of guilt. She hadn't called to say she'd be late. Again.
